author: wired staff
text: after 100 years of signalling distress at sea, the morse code warning sos is being replaced by a satellite system. the global maritime distress and safety system can pinpoint the location of any vessel on the high seas within 200 yards. dots and dashes were first used for a marine rescue off dover, england. but it was the titanic disaster of 1912 that prompted the adoption of sos -- three dots, followed by three dashes and three more dots -- as an international distress signal.
